publicationStmt.p: File created by Evolving Hands project, Newcastle University

div.ab:
Aug
August
6 Baghdad Received Sept 15th 1921
1921
Darling Father. We have had a quiet week. The plebiscite is
nearly finished throughout the country. Many districts, Ramadi,
Basrah, the Euphrates, Amarah, have added a
rider ryder
to the
papers swearing allegiance to Faisal "on condition that he
accepts British guidance." This has more than counteracted
the folly of Baghdad. In not a single case has any anti-
British provision been added + the Baghdad extremists are a
butt for the ridicule of all. I sent you two more of Faisal's
admirable speeches. On Monday there was a reception for him
given by the Armenians + Protestants. It was one of the prettiest
of all the Baghdad functions. It was given in the courtyard
in front of the Armenian church which was hung with carpets
+ covered with awnings. There are a few palm trees in
the court bearing now their heavy branches of dates.
The great fronds with their hanging crown of fruit looked
like huge Corinthian capitals carrying the awning roof.
Faisal, who catches at beauty, was delighted. He
called me up onto his dais, to sit on one side of him, with
the Armenian bishop on the other. I felt it was a little
public, but it seemed best not to make a fuss but
just to do as I was told. There were the usual two
hours of speeches, poems, sherbets + ices. His own
speech was unimportant - mere friendly encouragement
of the Armenian community.
I had a terrific day on Tuesday. I got up at 4.45,
motored at 5.45 with Mr Cornwallis to Ctesiphon -
we took Faisal there - office 10.30 to 3.30 with an
interval for lunch, home to wash + change, visit to
the Naqib 4.30 to 6, library committee 6 to 7, visit
to Sasun's sister in law
sister in law This could also be Simha Moshi-Haim, b.1869 d.unknown
7 to 7.30, Hamid Khan to
dinner 8 to 10. It was too much; I felt tired all next
day - however it was worth it.
The Ctesiphon expedition was an immense success. I

invited Faisal + 2 of his
ADC aide-de-camp s,
the Garbetts Sir Colin Campbell Garbett and his Wife, Lady Marjorie Josephine Garbett. , Fakhri Jamil
+ Mr Cornwallis, + I took Zaya with an excellent breakfast
of eggs, tongues, sardines + melons. It was wonderfully
interesting showing that splendid place to Faisal. He is an
inspiring tourist. After we had reconstructed the palace + seen
Chosroes sitting in it, I took him into the high mounds to the
south, whence we could see the Tigris, + told him the story
of the Arab conquest as Tabari records it, the fording of
the river + the rest of that magnificent tale. It was the
tale of his own people - you can imagine what it was
like reciting it to him. I don't know which of us was
the more thrilled. I had a good audience too in one of his
ADC aide-de-camp s, a Syrian called Rustam Haidar whom I like
very much indeed - he's an intelligent well educated
man + talks English admirably (though, if you'll forgive
me for saying so, not as well as I talk Arabic -
at which I'm a real dab now; so we always talk
Arabic.) Fakhri Jamil has a large estate on the bank
of the river opposite Ctesiphon + he brought over some of
his villagers with 4 lambs which they sacrificed to
Faisal just before breakfast - horrid. By this time,
though the visit was incognito, the whole village of
Salman Pak had become aware of Faisal's presence
+ assembled outside the ruins, but we kept them
outside + ourselves sat down under the shadow of
the curtain wall to the excellent breakfast which
Zaya had spread for us. It was very merry,
Faisal in great spirits. They had hunted out all
the school children + all the Sharifian flags they could
muster into the single street of Salman Pak as we drove
back through it.
Then the usual rushing morning, at the end of which I
feel more dead than alive even when I haven't got up

2
before 5. I couldn't rest in the afternoon because of my
appointment with the Naqib. I never loved the old man
more than that day, though it took him an hour +
a half to say his say. He also was in the highest
spirits + tremendously pleased with the part he has
played. " KhatunFemale title of nobility; counterpoint to 'khan'. " he said "you are my daughter, I will
tell you all that passed through my mind. I have never
since the coming of Sir Percy Cox acted contrary to his
advice or to the wish of the British Government. When I
saw that Faisal was fit to be king + knew that
the great
Govt Government
favoured him, I determined that I must
avoid all talk + gossip by rising myself in the Council
+ pronouncing him King. I thought: Shall I consult
Sir Percy Cox? + my own thoughts answered me. I
had made up my mind - if he disagreed with me I
could not change it. I am an old man, responsible
only to God. Therefore I consulted no one." That
was what he said - + he repeated it very often -
but isn't it fine? It's a privilege to deal with
gentlefolk + there's no greater gentleman than the Naqib.
So at the end of the day I came to Hamid Khan,
Mutasarrif of Karbala, cousin of the Agha Khan,
+ a really staunch adherent - He was immensely
interesting about the politics of Karbala + Najaf
but by that time I was so sleepy, that his voice
seemed to retire fainter + fainter into a dim
distance - + then I woke with a jump to
supply the right answer about 'Abdul Wahid, or
whoever it might be!
There was a curious episode in the middle of the

week about one of the newspapers. The editor in his
issue of Wednesday had quoted an article from an
Egyptian paper + one from the Echo de Paris about
French policy in Syria. He promised a leader on the
subject next day, but when next day came there
wasn't a leader + I, thinking that the editor had
recalled my warnings, dismissed the matter from
my mind. Not so the French consul - a snake in
the grass. He came in to complain to Sir Percy
of the leader that hadn't been written. Thereat
Sir Percy told me to make sure that it wouldn't
be written, + I sent a message to the creator.
Next day he came into the office at 7.30 +
said my message had come too late, the leader
had already been written + printed, but the
paper wasn't yet out + might he read it to
me? It was an article entitled Two policies,
pointing out + tracing historically the history
of French + British relations with Turkey +
with the Arabs + it was quite excellent;
it hit the nail on the head every time, but
the more justly it hit the more infuriated the
French consul would be. The editor said if I
didn't want it to be published he would suppress
the whole issue. I said I was really
reluctant to do that but I would like to
consult the High Commissioner. Sir Percy was at
breakfast. I gave him a brief outline of the
article + he decided that it had better

3 be suppressed, so I bought up the whole issue of the
paper + burnt it! And we have now purchased the
best of all weapons to use against the French consul
if he complains again. But I'm going to have his blood.
The Syrian papers, subsidized by the French, are full
of the most violent abuse of us + of Faisal
+ I've given my editors full permission to quote +
comment on these passages.
I gave Faisal an account of the whole transaction,
together with the suppressed article, + next day,
like the trump he is, he played into our hands.
There happened to be a reception at the Persian
school to which I went as usual. It was all the
more necessary to go because Muhammad Sadr
was the organizer of the function + I feared that
unsuitable things might be said, which my presence
would have a tendency to restrain. Muhammad
Sadr came in just before
the Amir Title used to refer to Faysal. . Everybody rose
at his entrance - + I sat tight + gave him the
salute I should give to anybody, after he had
sat down. He was put on the left of the Amir's
throne, while I was on the right. I got up with
alacrity for Faisal when he entered. (Next day one of the
Shi'ahs An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
came to the office + expostulated with me. I
replied "Why should I rise for Muhammad Sadr?
he is not even an 'alim An educated scholar of Islamic law. ." "By God, that's true"
he answered, + left a wiser man than he had
come.) - Such an immense beetle has just
flown into my room. I've invited it to leave -
Well - all the speeches + poems were perfectly

in order till the very last, when a young idiot
whom I've known for years - he's scarcely sane -
got up + recited an ode about the throne of
Beyrut + the mountains of Lebanon + the
desire of all Arabs. Faisal whispered to me "Do
you understand?" I said "Of course." He
went on "I think I must say a few words
on that." I cheered him on. And just as he
was going away he said "This is a private
meeting + nothing that is spoken here has
political importance, but I was sorry to
hear the ode of - Rashid, is his name?
(Rashid sank into the earth) + if I had
known he intended to recite it I would
have stopped him. I beg you to turn all
your thoughts to the work of creating an
Arab state in Mesopotamia, + to think of
nothing else."
His words were electric, the whole town is
talking of them - isn't he a good colleague?
I dined last night with Sir Aylmer to meet him.
It was a small male dinner - I was the only
woman. I sat by Faisal who was full of talk.
He is tremendously excited about Ibn Sa'ud's
claim to sovereignty over all our nomad tribes
- chiefly Fahad Beg of the 'Anizah. "I take witness
in God" he said "if we don't stop Ibn Sa'ud, in

4
three months' time there will be another battle at
Ctesiphon like that which you described to me."
But we shall stop him; his claims are absolutely
inadmissible.
This evening Nuri Pasha, Ja'far's brother in law
+
C.G.S. Chief of the General Staff , came to see me + we spent an hour
praising all the gods we knew for what has
been done here in the last 6 weeks. Faisal has
promised me a regiment of the Arab Army - the
Khatun Female title of nobility; counterpart of 'khan'. 's own. I shall presently ask you to
have their colours embroidered. Nuri proposes
that I should have an army corps!
Oh Father, isn't it wonderful. I sometimes think
I must be in a dream.
Sorry to say that it's desperately hot
again. As regards climate this is being the
Devil's own summer.
I must tell you another item of Nuri's conversation
- mind, you are not to repeat any of these things; I don't
wish to emulate Mrs Rosita Forbes. Nuri said "People
like to see you at the meetings for Faisal. Wherever you are
they know it will be all right. They think you keep Sir Percy
straight." I said "That's entirely untrue - it was Sir Percy's
policy from the first." "Yes" he said "I know. But it was yours
even before Sir Percy came. People know that you always
advocated an Arab state + it gives them confidence to see you."
It's an advantage isn't it, + one which doesn't always
accrue to us here below, to have been consistently of
the same mind from the very beginning!

I've got Ernest's letter + I'm writing to Herbert. I entirely agree
with Ernest, it's just what I've always expected, +
our success here is going to make things worse for them
there. Again, if I'm not being very egregious, I lay claim
to consistency from the first. I'm convinced you can't
be pan-Arab in Mesopotamia + pan-Jew in
Palestine.
Darling I've got your letter of July 6 with the
account of Mother's accident. She really is a
remarkable lady - I do hope she is better. Soon
I ought to hear of the success of the play.
Goodbye - I hope you are not bored
with my histories. It's such a comfort to
have someone to tell them to!
Your very loving daughter
Gertrude

Aug 6 1921
From Gertrude
Rec dated Aug 6 1921
Received Sep 15 1921
